title: Rare Reservoir holding — solid cashflow potential and great capital upside since 2016.
overview: Set on a huge 687m² parcel in family-friendly Reservoir, this classic mixes instant income potential with redevelopment upside. The five-bedroom layout rents in line with strong suburb averages, while the land size and position mean future value-adding (renovation, extension or subdivision subject to council) is realistic. With the property rising from $615k in 2016 to $905k in 2025 (a verified ~$290k increase), investors can see both steady capital growth and attractive yield opportunities in a suburb with improving rental fundamentals.
highlights: Median house price of roughly $865k–$920k – Reservoir has shown steady longer-term growth with great development opportunities. ￼
Strong rental demand: property portals report rising rental listings and tighter rental market conditions in recent years, which is positive for investor occupancy.

title: Rare Seaford block — bought dirt-cheap, delivered 30%+ capital growth in 3 years and strong rental demand
overview: Bought for $388K, this fantastic little find sits on a generous 687m² block in Seaford and captured the suburb’s rapid upswing — comparable local sales show the asset delivered roughly 31–42% capital growth within three years, while strong local rental demand pushed 3-bed rents into the $500–$600/week band. With subdivision/upgrade upside and steady yields from day one, this was a textbook value-add purchase for investors seeking both immediate cashflow and aggressive short-term capital uplift.
highlights: Seaford median house price currently sits in the mid-$800k range across public portals — attractive relative affordability for Melbourne’s southeast fringe.
Median house rents in Seaford run around $580–$590/week (strong yields for the suburb).
Local market showed clear gains from 2014 → 2017 (multiple nearby houses jumped from ~$320–$390k in 2014 to ~$510–$550k in 2017), demonstrating meaningful capital appreciation in just three years.
